head.hi:
A Cry of Distress from Alexander Hum-
boldt.

div.p:
—Berlin papers received by the City of
Baltimore contain the following card from Alex-
ander Humboldt:

Suffering beneath the pressure of a still in-
creasing correspondence, amounting to between
sixteen hundred and two thousand communica-
tions per annum, and embracing letters, printed
pamphlets on matters with which I am wholly
unacquainted, manuscripts concerning which my
opinion is desired, projeetsprojects for emigration and
colonizing, the sending of models, machines and
natural curiosities, requests of contributions to
collections of autographs, offers to take charge
of my domestic concersconcerns, to cheer and enliven me,
&c., &c., I must again publicly urge all persons
having my welfare at heart to exert their influ-
ence in my behalf, that individuals in both con-
tinents may no longer busy themselves with my
person and make of my house an intelligence of-
fice; and that I be allowed, in the declining state
of my physical powers, to enjoy some rest and
leisure to attend to my duties. May this cry for
relief, which I utter with reluctance and after
much reflection, not meet and unfriendly inter-
pretation.
